question_details.query: Which interventions can increase invertebrate abundance on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Creating hole habitats (>50 mm) increased the abundance of brown crabs on and around structures in one study, while another study reported mixed effects on invertebrate abundances when holes were implemented alongside pits, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material [3434].
- Constructing artificial reefs with specific materials/designs increased some invertebrates: breakwaters made of bags of oyster shells recruited more oysters and ribbed mussels than “ReefBall” breakwaters, and in one case “sea-friendly” concrete pyramid reefs had higher overall abundance than plinth‑pole structures after three years [2259].
- Other surface‑complexity interventions showed mixed effects on invertebrate abundance depending on species, site or surface orientation: creating grooves (1–50 mm) [3448], pits (1–50 mm) [3455], combined grooves and small protrusions/ridges/ledges (1–50 mm) [3452], textured surfaces (≤1 mm) [3449], and adding short (1–50 mm) [3450] or long (>50 mm) [3451] flexible habitats.

question_details.query: What are the benefits of creating rock pools on intertidal artificial structures for overall species richness?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across 12 replicated, controlled studies, rock pools created on intertidal artificial structures supported higher combined macroalgae, invertebrate and/or fish species richness and/or diversity than structure surfaces without pools in nine studies, while three reported similar richness; one study also found created pools had similar combined richness to natural rock pools, and another reported lower richness for combined mobile invertebrates and fishes in created pools [3476]. Several moderators were reported: shore level did not affect species richness in some studies, pool depth often had no effect, tilted pools had higher richness than horizontal ones, and adding short flexible habitats had mixed effects depending on species group and site [3476]. A before-and-after study reported that creating pools alongside reducing structure slope increased combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness on the structure [3476]. One study reported that creating rock pools did not increase fish species richness on and around the structure [3476].
